title-group.article-title: A simple and unified displacement field for three-dimensional vibration analysis of prestressed circular plates

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical and Electro-Mechanical Engineering, National Sun Yat-Sen University, Taiwan, R.O.C.

author-notes.corresp: Chorng-Fuh Liu, Department of Mechanical and Electro-Mechanical Engineering, National Sun Yat-Sen University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan, R.O.C. Email: liucf@mail.nsysu.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study a simple displacement field is proposed for finite element vibration analysis of circular plates. The displacement field is a combination of a conventional field, which is very popular for three-dimensional vibration analysis of circular plates or cylinders, and another field, which is most general for axisymmetric vibration. The investigation here is intended, through mathematical formulation and examples, to verify the existence of coupled axisymmetric vibration modes. These modes cannot be found by conventional displacement field, but can easily be revealed by the present model. Validity and accuracy of the proposed displacement field to show all the prominent vibration modes of circular plates or cylinder-like structures is also demonstrated by comparing results using the present method with those of a three-dimensional finite element analysis and experiments.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: It is well known that the axisymmetric vibration of circular and annular plates shows two types of modes – one in the radial-thickness (r-z) plane, which involves displacements in the radial and thickness directions, and the other in the circumferential direction, which involves only the circumferential displacements. These two modes are uncoupled (Leissa and So, 1995). Physically, there is no reason why a circular plate can develop only uncoupled vibration modes. Coupled modes might appear as higher vibration modes or under some particular conditions. In this study, we will use prestressed circular plate as an example to show the existence of coupled axisymmetric vibration modes.

Most vibration analysis of prestressed circular plates reported in the literature can be classified as those based on classical plate theory, such as Rosen and Libai (1975), Gupta and Lal (1979), Ramaiah and Vijaya Kumar (1978), Ramaiah (1980), Narita (1985), and Rim and Lee (1993); or based on first-order shear-deformation plate theory, such as Yang and Shieh (1988), Latha Nayar et al. (1994), and Rao and Neetha (2003). Higher-order plate theory was employed by Chen and Huang (1998). Plate theories are simplified theories of elasticity, and each has its own particular assumptions or approximatioms. Classical plate theory uses Kirchhoff assumptions, which neglect transverse normal and shear deformations, and rotary inertia is omitted, too. First-order shear deformation theory remedies the classical theory by taking transverse shear deformation into account and assuming constant transverse shear strains across the thickness. Higher-order theories expand the displacements in terms with higher order powers of thickness coordinate and introduce more variables. From experience, classical plate theory is suitable for analysis of thin plates. For moderately thick plates, first-order shear-deformation plate theory is generally better than the classical theory, although first-order shear-deformation plate theory might overestimate results in some cases and underestimate in others. This is also the case with the higher-order theory, although it is theoretically better.
It is also quite surprising that to the authors’ knowledge, there is no report on vibration of prestressed circular plates based on 3D elasticity in the literature.

In the present study, a modified displacement field is proposed; a finite element formulation based on elasticity is developed first and then incorporated with the conventional and the proposed displacement fields, respectively. Mathematical terms in the formulation will be examined carefully, and terms and factors that are key to revealing coupled axisymmetric modes or that lead to uncoupling modes are highlighted. Also, to test the validity and accuracy of the present method in vibration analysis of circular plates, especially its capability to reveal all the prominent vibration modes, comparisons among the present method, a three-dimensional finite element analysis, and experiments are also made.

sec.title: 2. General formulation
sec.p: Now the variational statement for vibration of circular plates with initial stresses has the following form: (5)0=∫t∫vol[σrδɛr+σzδɛz+σθδɛθ+τzθδγzθg. g+ τrθδγrθ+τrzδγrz+σr*δɛrN+σz*δɛzN+σθ*δɛθNg +τzθ*δγzθN+τrθ*δγrθN+τrz*δγrzN -ρ(u·δu·+v·δv·+w·δw·)]dvdt

The elemental equations, equation (6), should be assembled, boundary conditions imposed, and we then end up with the following system equation with which vibration frequency ω and vibration mode {X} of circular plates with preloadings are calculated. (7)[K+G]{X}=ω2[M]{X}

sec.title: 3. Conventional displacement field
sec.p: The conventional and most popular displacement field for vibration analysis of circular plates may be given as: (8)u(r,θ,z,t)=ur(r,z)cosnθsinωtv(r,θ,z,t)=uθ(r,z)sinnθsinωtw(r,θ,z,t)=uz(r,z)cosnθsinωt where t is time, n is circumferential wave number, and ω is vibration frequency in radians/second. This displacement field has been used by many researchers, for example Gladwell and Vijay (1975), Buchanan and Yii (2002), Leissa and So (1995), Zhou et al. (2003), and others. Using equation (8) in the general finite element formulation in the last section, submatrices in the elemental equation, equation (6), can be derived with their details as follows: (k11)ij=∫[A(c11N11+c13N10/r+c31N01/r +c33N00/r2+c66N22)+B(c55n2N00/r2)]πrdrdz (k12)ij=∫[A(c13nN10/r+c33nN00/r2) -Bc55(nN01/r-nN00/r2)]πrdrdz=(k21)ji (k13)ij=∫A(c12N12+c32N02/r+c66N21)πrdrdz=(k31)ji (k22)ij=∫[A(c33n2N00/r2)+B(c44N22 +c55(N11-N10/r-N01/r+N00/r2)]πrdrdz (k23)ij=∫[Ac32nN02/r-Bc44nN20/r]πrdrdz=(k32)ji (k33)ij=∫[A(c22N22+c66N11)+Bc44n2N00/r2]πrdrdz (g11)ij=∫A[(σr*N11+σz*N22+σθ*N00/r2 +τrz*(N12+N21)]+Bσθ*n2N00/r2)πrdrdz (g12)ij=∫[Aσθ*nN00/r2+Bσθ*nN00/r2]πrdrdz=(g21)ji (g22)ij=∫B[(σr*N11+σz*N22+σθ*N00/r2 +τrz*(N12+N21)]+Aσθ*n2N00/r2)πrdrdz (g33)ij=∫A[(σr*N11+σz*N22 +τrz*(N12+N21)]+Bσθ*n2N00/r2)πrdrdz (m11)ij=∫AρN00πrdrdz=(m33)ij (9)(m22)ij=∫BρN00πrdrdz Where N00=NiNj Nt0=∂Ni∂xtNj N0s=Ni∂Nj∂xs Nts=∂Ni∂xt∂Nj∂xst,s=1or2 x1=r,x2=z

Ni is the shape function corresponding to the ith node in an element, therefore, subscript i, j = 1 ∼ p. The letter x with a subscript represents coordinate r or z. It is r if the subscript is 1, otherwise it is z. ρ is density. Other submatrices not shown are all zero. For axisymmetric vibration (n = 0), A = 2 and B = 0; when n is not zero, A = B = 1.

After careful examination of the terms in each submatrices of equation (9), it is observed that [m12], [m23], [k12], [k23], [g12], and [g23] are all zero for axisymmetric vibration, and these are the coupling matrices between {U} and {V}, and between {V} and {W}. [m22], [k22] and [g22], which represent circumferential inertia and stiffness, are also zero. In that case, the displacement field of equation (8) can only show axisymmetric vibration modes which involve only displacements in r- and z-direction as has been demonstrated in Leissa and So (1995) for circular cylinders without prestressing and here for cases with preloadings. To get vibration modes in the circumferential direction, Leissa and So (1995) proposed a complementary set of displacements of equation (8) by replacing cosnθ by sinnθ, and conversely. For n ≠ 0, this complementary set gives the same frequencies and mode shapes as equation (8), with a 90/n degrees offset in the θ-direction. For n = 0, the complementary set derives circumferential vibrating modes that involve only circumferential displacement, with displacements in the other two coordinate directions being zero. Details of the submatrices by this complementary set can be obtained by reversing A and B and replacing n by -n in equation (9). In other words, equation (8) and its complementary set can only give the two uncoupled types of axisymmetric modes - u-w modes and v modes, separately, whether the plate is with prestressing or not. The question is: do the assumed displacement field, equation (8), and its complementary set include all the possible axisymmetric modes in real situations, especially when some complicating effects, such as preloading, are imposed? To address this issue, a more general displacement field for the modeling of vibration of circular plates will be proposed in the next section.

sec.title: 4. Proposed displacement field
sec.p: Because from previous researches equation (8) has proved to be valid and accurate for most cases, especially nonaxisymmetric vibration analysis, modification of it so that it is more capable of simulating axisymmetric vibration of circular plates is our aim.
A general axisymmetric displacement field should have the form: (10)u(r,z,t)=ur(r,z)sinωtv(r,z,t)=uθ(r,z)sinωtw(r,z,t)=uz(r,z)sinωt
Combining equations (8) and (10), a unified displacement field is proposed: (11)u(r,θ,z,t)=ur(r,z)cosnθsinωtv(r,θ,z,t)=uθ(r,z)sinnθsinωt +α*uθ(r,z)cosnθsinωtuz(r,θ,z,t)=uz(r,z)cosnθsinωt

The value of α is taken as either 0 or 1. For n = 0, then α = 1, equation (11) becomes equation (10) and has the most general capability to simulate axisymmetric vibration of circular plates. For the analysis of nonaxisymmetric vibration, n ≠ 0 and α = 0, equation (11) is the same as equation (8). By using equation (11), we combine the generality of equation (10) and the accuracy of equation (8) and are supposed to derive all the modes provided by equation (8) and its complementary set, and more if they exist.

Substituting equation (11) into the strain-displacement relations and the other equations shown in section 2, equation (6) is derived with details of the submatrices as follows: (k11)ij=∫[(1+α)(c11N11+c13N10/r +c31N01/r+c33N00/r2 +c66N22)+(1-α)(c55n2N00/r2)]πrdrdz (k12)ij=∫[(1+α)(c13nN10/r+c33nN00/r2) +(1-α)(c55nN00/r2-c55nN01/r)]πrdrdz (k13)ij=∫[(1+α)((c12N12+c32N02/r+c66N21)] πrdrdz (k22)ij=∫[(1+α)(c33n2N00/r2+c44α2N22+c55α2N11 -c55α2N10/r-c55α2N01/r+c55α2N00/r2) +(1-α)(c33n2α2N00/r2+c44N22+c55N11 -c55N10/r-c55N01/r+c55N00/r2)]πrdrdz (k23)ij=∫[(1+α)c32nN02/r-(1-α)c44nN20/r]πrdrdz (k33)ij=∫[(1+α)(c22N22+c66N11) +(1-α)c44n2N00/r2]πrdrdz (k21)ji=(k12)ij(k31)ji=(k13)ij(k32)ji=(k23)ij (g11)ij=∫[(1+α)(σr*N11+τrz*(N12+N21)+σθ*N00/r2 +σz*N22)+(1-α)(σθ*n2N00/r2)]πrdrdz (g12)ij=∫[(1+α)(σθ*nN00/r2+τzθ*α(N02-N20)/r +τrθ*α(N01-N10)/r)+(1-α)(σθ*nN00/r2)] πrdrdz (g22)ij=∫[(1+α)(α(σr*N11+τrz*(N12+N21)+σθ*N00/r2 +σz*N22))+n2σθ*N00/r2+τzθ*αn(N02+N20)/r +τrθ*αn(N10+N01)/r)+(1-α)(σr*N11+σz*N22 +σθ*(N00+αn2N00)/r2+τrz*(N12+N21) -τzθ*αn(N02+N20)/r-τrθ*αn(N10+N01)/r)] πrdrdz (g33)ij=∫[(1+α)(σr*N11+τrz*(N12+N21)+σz*N22) +(1-α)(σθ*n2N00/r2)]πrdrdz (g21)ji=(g12)ij (m11)ij=(m33)ij=ρ∫(1+α)(N00)πrdrdz (12)(m22)ij=ρ∫[(1+α)αN00+(1-α)N00]πrdrdz

Inspecting the terms in each submatrices [kpq], [gpq], and [mpq] of equation (12) and comparing with those in equation (9), it is found that
When axisymmetric vibration (n = 0) of circular plates without preloadings is concerned, [k12] and [k23] in both equations (9) and (12) are zero, i.e., u-w modes are uncoupled from v modes for both the conventional and the proposed displacement fields.
However, for n = 0, [k22] and [m22] are zero in equation (9) while they are not zero in equation (12). That means that, for cases without preloadings, uncoupled axisymmetric u-w modes and v modes can be derived altogether with the present displacement field in a single analysis, while the conventional method needs equation (8) and its complementary set, respectively, in separate analyses.
The proposed displacement field is able to show coupled axisymmetric vibration modes while the conventional displacement field is not, for prestressed circular plates. When vibration of circular plates with preloadings is concerned, i.e. when the geometric matrix is taken into account, the present displacement field predicts coupled modes which involve u, v, and w even for axisymmetric vibration. It can be perceived from [g12] in equation (12) that it is not necessarily zero for n = 0. Since [g12] is the coupling matrix of displacements u and v, a nonzero [g12] represents coupled u and v, and eventually leads to coupled u, v, and w. Using the conventional displacements still leads to uncoupled axisymmetric modes, the same as the cases without preloadings. ([g12] in equation (9) is zero for n = 0).

The key to revealing the coupled axisymmetric modes in the present formulation is the appearance of the initial stresses, τzθ* and τrθ* in [g12] of equation (12). If preloading does not induce τzθ* or τrθ*, coupled modes would not appear. Demonstrated in Tables 1 to 3 are nodal values (mode shapes) of the first axisymmetric modes of a circular hollow cylinder (a thick annular plate) under three different conditions: case (a) with one end fixed and a uniform fz(does not induce τzθ* or τrθ*) applied on the other end and case (b) one end fixed and a uniform line loading fθ(induces τzθ* and τrθ*) acting on the outer edge of the other end surface, and case (c) the inner surface of the annular cylinder is fixed and two uniform line loadings fθ are applied on the outer edges of the two end surfaces and in opposite directions, which also induces τzθ* and τrθ*. Figure 1 shows the global node numbering of the finite element mesh. Figure 1.

From Table 1, it is found that vibration occurs in the circumferential direction only. This is because a uniform fz on one end surface does not induce τzθ* or τrθ*, decoupling of u-w and v is obvious. It is also notable that obtaining the circumferential vibrating mode with the proposed unified displacements is straightforward. In conventional analysis, this mode can only be obtained by complementary set of equation (8).

sec.title: 5. Comparisons with 3D finite element and experiments
sec.p:
Although the superiority of the present displacement field over the conventional one has been demonstrated, it is still a displacement set assumed to perform vibration analysis of circular plates and the like. It is of concern if some prominent vibration modes could be missed by the proposed set of displacements. Therefore, comparisons with analysis by a general three-dimensional (3-D) finite element and experiments will be conducted to verify the completeness and accuracy of the present method. Although three-dimensional finite elements are cumbersome and time-consuming to work with (compared with the present 2-D approach), they are based on three-dimensional elasticity and are considered the most general finite elements. Thus the three-dimensional finite elements should be able to reveal all the possible vibration modes, if the number of elements is sufficiently large in the analysis. In Wang and Williams (1996), the frequencies of the first 21 modes of a thick circular hollow cylinder with axial length 522.9 mm, outer radius a = 238.05 mm, and inner radius b = 158.45 mm, and made of isotropic mild steel with E = 207 GPa, ρ = 7800 kg/m3, Poisson’s ratio 0.3, and free boundary condition are obtained via the three-dimensional 8-node linear finite element and experimental method. The same problem is solved by the present method using a two-dimensional 8-node isoparametric quadratic element with a mesh of 6 by 36 elements in the radial and axial directions, respectively. Table 4 compares the frequencies for the free cylinder obtained from the present method with those obtained by a 3-D finite element analysis and experiments of Wang and Williams (1996). From the table, some conclusions can be drawn:
Discrepancy between the present solutions and experiments is generally less than 1% and the present method obtains the lowest frequencies for all the modes among the three approaches. The accuracy of the present method is thus verified.
With increasing frequency, appearing order of vibration modes exactly match each other, one by one, between the present solutions and experiments. Comparing experiments, the general three-dimensional finite elements occasionally obtain switched modes, e.g., the 7th and 8th modes, for some unknown reasons.
Not only can the present method obtain all the first 21 modes of the test cylinder in Wang and Williams (1996), there is also a mode with frequency 5702 Hz that appears in the present analysis and is not shown by the two approaches of Wang and Williams (1996).

sec.title: 6. Concluding remarks
sec.p: A simple and unified displacement field has been presented for the determinations of vibration frequencies of circular plates with preloadings. The proposed displacement field is a combination of a very general one for axisymmetric vibration analysis and a conventional one that is aimed at both nonaxisymmetric and axisymmetric analyses, though some transformation of the conventional displacements is needed to obtain specific axisymmetric modes. Detailed finite element formulations by the present displacement set and those of the conventional one have been demonstrated and careful comparisons have been made. It is shown that when the plate is prestressed, coupled axisymmetric modes that involved simultaneous vibrations in the three coordinate directions can be obtained with the proposed displacements. This is what the conventional displacement set or its complementary one cannot achieve, which obtains none of these modes. Even for axisymmetric vibration for circular plates without preloadings, the present displacement set is able to obtain uncoupled axisymmetric u-w modes and v modes altogether in a single analysis while these uncoupled modes can only be derived in separate analyses by the conventional displacements and its complementary displacement, respectively.

To test the ability of the proposed formulation to completely present all the prominent vibration modes of circular plates, the frequencies of a free annular cylinder by the present analysis are compared with those by a 3-D finite element analysis and experiments. It is observed that the present results are close to those of the experiments with the present frequencies always being lower. In addition, the present results show one more vibration mode that is not obtained by the experiments and the 3-D finite element analysis.

We may therefore conclude that the present displacement field, when incorporated with other methods such as the finite element method, may represent a proper alternative for vibration analysis of circular plates or cylinder-like structures which are generated with generatrices and with or without general axisymmetric preloadings.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
